position.marginalia_text: sequitur: et natura co[e]pit suum compare[m] vt Inimicu[m], & ad se invicem co[n]tinuerunt, & continent , quoniam A[n]i[m]a corpus introvit. Istud punctum est secundu[m] punctum martis secundu[m] Hermete[m]: Secundu[m] vero ordinem est Iovis, in domo cui[us] posuimus Martem. Et quare ibi appositus fuit videatur particula nostra[e] divisionis, sub titulo Cineritij. C[um] Res a lopis mundata. Idem dicit Rodianus cum Embryone reducit. Notetis Embryon. Embryon enim est fructum carnis, seu massa, ex qua natura format in matrice foetum et dipsonit o[mn]ia membra sua: sic istud punctu[m] est massa seu lapis, ex quo totu[m] magisteriu[m] perficitur. Item istud punctum [etc]

marginalia.translation: [And truth] follows and nature approaches its fellow like an enemy and in turn they continue and contain, because the breath enters the body. This point is the second point of Mars, according to Hermes. The second order is Jupiter. In his house we put Mars. Note the embryo, for it is the fruit of the flesh or the mass of which nature forms the foetus in the dam and disposes all its limbs.Thus, this point is mass or stone of which all the magisterial is perfected. Likewise, this point etc.

position.marginalia_text: Et sic notetis quod aqua viscosa, et sulfur, materia sunt o[mn]i[u]m metallorum, Argenti vivi. Hoc ide[m] dicit Geber cum definit Argentum viuum dicens. Argentu[m] viuum est aqua viscosa, in visceribus terra[e], substa[n]tia[e] subtilis Alba[e] terra[e] per caloren temperatissimu[m] vnita totali vnione per minima: quovsq[ue] humidu[m] co[n]temperetur a sicco, et siccum ab Humido a[e]qualiter. Notetis ergo Aqua[m] viscosa[m], et substa[n]tia[m] Alba[m], quam dicimus esse etia[m] materia[m] Argenti. Item notetis per calore[m]

marginalia.translation:
And thus note that and sulfur are matterof all metalls, of mercury. Geber says this when defining mercury. He says when he defines mercury: Mercury is a viscous water, in the offsprings of soil, of the fine substance of white soil, united in total union through the most temperate heat, through the smallest thing
Therefore, note the viscous water and white substance, which we also say to be the matter of silver. Aslo, note that through heat [...].
